The disadvantage of this is that a variation in  _B_  _DC_  causes IC and\, as a result\, VCE to change\, thus changing the Q\-point of the transistor\.

<span style="color:#ff0000"> __This makes the base\-bias circuit extremely beta\-dependent and unpredictable\.__ </span>

Hence base bias is used in switching circuits where the transistor is either in saturation or cut off but is rarely used in linear circuits\.

<span style="color:#336600">2</span>  <span style="color:#336600">\- Emitter Bias/ Emitter Feedback Configuration:</span>

Adding a resistor  \(RE\) to the emitter circuit stabilizes the bias circuit\.

![](l4.4-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor-ii-img/l44-dc-biasing-bipolar-junction-transistor-ii_15.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Idea is to help make base bias more predictable with negative feedback\, which negates any attempted change in collector current with an opposing change in base voltage\.</span>

If the collector current tries to increase\, the emitter voltage increases\, causing an increase in base voltage because VB = VE \+ VBE\.

Increase in base voltage reduces the voltage across RB\, reducing the base current and keeping the collector current from increasing\.

While this is better for linear circuits than base bias\, it is still dependent on ßDC and is not as predictable as voltage\-divider bias\. To calculate IE\, you can write Kirchhoff’s voltage law \(KVL\) around the base circuit\.

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system
